conclusion: Determine the maximum distance d from the optical axis for which light can emerge from the spherical surface.
Light rays incident perpendicular to the flat base are refracted into the glass without changing direction.
Light will emerge if it is refracted at the spherical surface and does not undergo total internal reflection.
Critical angle θc is given by sin θc = 1/n.
Calculate θc: sin θc = 2/3, θc = sin^(-1)(2/3).
At the spherical surface, angle of incidence i and angle of refraction r are related by Snell's Law: n sin i = sin r.
Since light just barely emerges, r = 90° and sin r = 1.
At the critical angle, sin i = 1/n and i must be equal to θc.
In the right triangle formed by the radius, incident ray, and distance d: cos i = d/R.
Since cos i = sin(90° - i) and i = θc, cos θc = d/R, so d = R cos θc.
Calculate cos θc: cos^2 θc = 1 - (2/3)^2 = 5/9, cos θc = √(5/9) = √5/3.
The maximum distance from the optical axis for the incident ray corresponding to the emerging light is (√5/3) R.
